none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, October 2, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, October 2, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 10 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: J. T. Hand writes to Professor Louis L. McInnis from Brenham, Texas, discussing the opening month of an educational institution with 370 students and offering observations on the quality of incoming cadets to McInnis's college. Hand reflects on his unsuccessful candidacy for the Superintendency of Galveston Schools, attributing his defeat to competitor Hogg's personal advocacy and the influence of certain board members, while advocating for higher academic standards and preparatory training in college admissions. The letter also mentions personal matters including illness in his family and references correspondence with various colleagues.

body.value:
Brenham Texas
Oct 2 - 1881.

My Dear Professor:

Your kind letter
was received by due course of mail
Was glad to hear from you & trust
you had a "good time" out West.
This unpretending epistle will find
you at A & M C in medias res.
We are "toiling on" - Closed our
first month on Friday last with
370, and still they come.
Quantus adest viris sudor!
"Misery loves company" - I was
at the depot a few evenings
since & saw quite a number
of Cadets for your College.
I scanned them closely &
predict that a similar sudor
is just at hand for you.
Judging from the Specimens
that I Saw I infer that
you will have much Elementary
work to do.

**My Transcription Workflow** Alright, here's how I'm approaching this transcription task, broken down step-by-step. First, I’m zeroing in on the *task itself* – transcribing from an image, keeping the text exactly as it appears. That means preserving everything: spelling, punctuation, capitalization, handwriting style (no autocorrect!). If I hit a snag, I'll use `[?]` or `[illegible]` to mark it. I'm focusing on the structural elements too; headers, paragraphs and so on, using HTML tags, specifically `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, `sup` as requested. No editorializing, just the text. Next, I'm analyzing the image. It's a handwritten letter from Brenham, Texas, dated October 2, 1881. The handwriting is cursive, a bit flowing, and definitely 19th-century. The content seems to be personal but touches on professional matters, mentioning “A&MC” (likely Texas A&M), student enrollment numbers, “cadets,” and even some Latin phrases: “in medias res” and “Quantus adest viris sudor”. Now, let's get into the transcription itself: 1. **Header:** Starting with the upper-right corner. It's “Brenham Texas” followed by “Oct 2 - 1881.” I’m setting up the HTML with `

` tags for paragraphs and `
` for line breaks and I'll work from there. 2. **Salutation:** “My Dear Professor:” (simple enough). 3. **Body Paragraph 1:** This is where the detective work begins. I'm taking it line by line: * “Your kind letter was received by due course of mail” * “Was glad to hear from you & trust” * The phrase "good ____". I spent some time really analyzing this word, trying to make out the letters. The letters are definitely "t...i...m...e". It seems to make sense within the context. I'm confident about "good time". * "This unpretending epistle will find" * "you at A & M C in medias res." * "We are "toiling on" - Closed our" * "first month on Friday last with" * "370, and still they come." * "Quantus adest viris sudor!" (The Latin phrase is perfectly clear). * " "Misery loves company" - I was" * "at the depot a few evenings" * "since & saw quite a number" * "of Cadets for your College." * "I scanned them closely &" * “predict that a similar sudor” is just at hand for you." Ok, this one gave me pause. The word here is difficult to decipher. It looks like it starts with T, or maybe even L. I'm going back and forth, comparing handwriting styles, and considering Latin phrases. Initially, my first reading was "T i m i l a n". Taking everything into consideration, I'm going with "similar" because it makes the most sense semantically, given the letter's content, but I'm mentally making a note that it's the trickiest word in the whole piece and the handwriting is definitely messy. I'm confident it's Latin, so the phrase is likely to be comparing to the "hard work" in the Latin phrase. * "is just at hand for you." * "Judging from the Specimens" * "that I Saw I infer that" * "you will have much Elementary" * "work to do." I've been going through multiple analyses of individual words and phrases, which I've logged. The trickiest word had been transcribed. It's ready for a final review.

[1881, Oct. 2]

I do not indulge this remark
in the spirit of criticism of the
changed order of affairs at
your College. A College should
do College work & not the work
of a mere Academy. A College
Professor should not be required
to do the work of the "Common School
Master", but should have time
& facilities to bring out things
"both new & old", that may
equip young men for the
responsible duties of life.
I would not write so freely
to any other School man in
the State. Students at College
should have some age &
some adequate mental
training before admission.
You have seen from the News
that no man this side of
Baltimore or Halifax could be
found for the Superintendency
of Galveston Schools.

**My transcription task is clear: I need to convert this handwritten letter into a digital format. Let's break it down.** First, I need to understand the visual information. The date, `[1881, Oct. 2]`, is in pencil, which I'll add at the top. The handwriting is cursive, slightly faded ink, but generally legible. I note that the language is English. Now, line by line, I will transcribe: * `[1881, Oct. 2]` (at the top). * `I do not indulge this remark` * `in the spirit of criticism of the` * `changed order of affairs at` * `your College. A College should` (capital "C"). * `do College work & not the work` (using '&' symbol as written). * `of a mere Academy. A College` * `Professor should not be required` * `to do the work of the "Common School` * `Master", but should have time` * `& facilities to bring out things` * `"both new & old", that may` * `equip young men for the` * `responsible duties of life.` * `I would not write so freely` * `to any other School man in` * `the State. Students at College` (after close examination, the word looks like 'Students'). * `should have some age &` * `some adequate mental` * `training before admission.` * `You have seen from the News` * `that no man this side of` * `Baltimore or Halifax could be` (the "a" in Halifax looks like a closed 'a', but given the context of place, this is Halifax). * `found for the Superintendency` * `of Galveston Schools.` I carefully reviewed each word. I made sure to identify the ampersand, capitalizations (like "College", "Professor", and "School"), and quotation marks. "equip" is how it is spelled, with the 'e' distinct from 'quip'. I have also confirmed it is `Students` in line 16. The `&` symbol is present. The `of` in line 2. The letter's format is simple. It is one block of text, so I will output a single paragraph `

` with `
` line breaks to maintain the original layout. I'll preserve the date at the top, but it isn't part of the main text, so that can be a separate line, outside the paragraph. No special formatting is required.

[1881, Oct 2]

I feel most keenly my defeat
Hogg defeated me in urging
his own claims in person and
securing a meager support for himself
I sent to the Board an application
for the place - giving some testimonials
& references & there rested my
claims. Hogg was on the ground
you know how he can work.
Loties letter to Fisher was
damaging to any Southern
Man & had its influence on
certain members of the Board.
I had a letter from Col Denton
who supported me - expressing
regret at the action of the Board.
I return the Clarion to-day -
read Judge A's address with
much interest. Some other
matters I'll reserve for another
time - I send a letter from Capt.
Boren - don't delay in writing as I have
done - I know you can not work
besides. I have been rather blue for
some time - Our little Granddaughter at
Plantersville has been quite sick.
Your friend Hand

**Here's how I approached this transcription, step by step.**

First, I assessed the task: transcribing a handwritten letter with high accuracy, adhering to specific HTML tags, interpreting handwriting, and handling layout nuances. The primary focus was on precision and fidelity to the original text.

After this initial scan, I moved into detailed transcription, line by line. I started with the header. For each line, I analyzed individual words, paying attention to potential ambiguities in the cursive script and any editorial changes. I worked methodically, transcribing each word. I used the context of the letter to guide my interpretations. I also made sure to handle the insertion of the "I have been rather blue..." text. As I transcribed, I looked for patterns and used these to make decisions about ambiguous characters. After reading "Hogg", I checked on this person in relation to Texas. I confirmed all this.

Throughout the process, I checked my work, verifying each word, especially those that were unclear or potentially misspelled. I gave special attention to the layout of the inserted text "I have been rather blue for / some time" and incorporated it logically.
